msDesc.head: Fifteenth-century anthology made up of composite parts, comprising poems on good manners and religious devotion, the Brut chronicle, and the Libelle of English Policy

physDesc.p: Composite: in five parts, A || B || C || D || E , produced seperately and bound in the fifteenth century

supportDesc.extent:
ii (modern endleaves, paper, with two unfoliated notes) + 1-2 (fifteenth-century endleaves, parchment) + 3-205 + i (modern endleaf, paper, foliated 206)
280 195
supportDesc.collation: 12 (fols. 1r-2v), 28 (fols. 3r-10v), 38 (fols. 11r-18v), 412-1 (fols. 19r-29v, seventh folio excised), 58 (fols. 30r-37v), 68 (fols. 30r-45v), 78 (fols. 46r-53v), 820-1 (fols. 54r-72v, second folio excised), 920 (fols. 73r-92v), 1020 (fols. 93r-112v), 113+18 (fols. 113r-133v: fols. 113-115 are the first three leaves of a quire of six leaves, with the corresponding stubs after fol. 133; fols. 116-133 are a quire of 18 leaves inserted in the middle of this first quire), 1218-1 (fols. 134r-150v, eighteenth folio excised), 1320-2 (fols. 151r-168v, nineteenth and twentieth folios excised), 1426-1 (fols. 169r-193v, twenty-third folio excised), 158 (fols. 194r-201v), 164 (fols. 202r-205v). Many leaf signatures still visible.
supportDesc.condition: Extensive wormholes throughout, especially on flyleaves and corners of pages.

binding.p: White parchment binding over pasteboards, c. seventeenth century [?].

history.provenance: Fol. 2r contains a table of contents in a near-contemporary hand, suggesting that although the composite parts were produced seperately they were bound into one volume soon after in the fifteenth century.
Fol. 205r bears the ownership mark Rychard Turnowre in a c. 1500 hand.

The whole volume identifiable as item 34 in the 1577 catalogue of the books of John Thynne at Longleat (Kate Harris, 'An Augustan Episode in the History of the Collection of Medieval Manuscripts at Longleat House;,English Medieval Book, ed. A.S.G. Edwards, et al. (British Library, 2000), 233-247 at 234)

The manuscript was owned by Thomas Thynne, Viscount Weymouth (1640–1714); listed in the Longleat catalogue of 1702 (Harris, op. cit., 234). The shelfmark IX. D. 69 on fol. 2r is in the hand of George Harbin (1665-1744), Thomas Thynne's librarian, who shelfmarked many other manuscripts in the collection at Longleat. Harbin was a librarian from 1699, and died in 1744..
It was then owned by Richard Rawlinson (1690–1755).

From this period, there is a letter on fol. 1r by E. U[mfreville] (1702?-86), who annotated many of Rawlinson's manuscripts, dated 25 March 1750 containing information about the contents of the manuscript.
history.acquisition: Bequeathed to the Bodleian in 1755 by Richard Rawlinson on his death.

recordHist.source: Description by Charlotte Ross, Sept. 2022. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1895). Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 290 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 291

ref.title: MWM: Manuscripts of the West Midlands

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: Kate Harris, 'An Augustan Episode in the History of the Collection of Medieval Manuscripts at Longleat House',English Medieval Book, ed. A.S.G. Edwards, et al. (British Library, 2000), 233-247

altIdentifier.idno: MS. Rawl. poet. 32 - pastedown and endleaf (fols. 1-2)

msItem.note: Formerly pastedown.

msItem.title: Prose note on the geography of the British Isles
msItem.note: Fifteenth-century hand.

msItem.incipit:
Ther benne yn yngelande xxxv scherys þ[ ]
And v mll & xj parich cherches
msItem.explicit:
þt ys CCC xxij li
vjs viij d

msItem.title: Prophecy
msItem.incipit:
Whanne faith faileth saw
And willes of lordis be ld
msItem.explicit:
Thanne shall þis lond Albio[n]
Be brought o confucion
msItem.note: Sometimes attributed to Chaucer, for instance by Caxton, 1477[?].

msItem.title: Be cleanly clad
msItem.incipit:
Be clenly clad hym of
Passe nat thi dis kepe thi
msItem.explicit:
Wherfore pursue peas in all thi life
Loue thi neighboures & gete þe a good name
msItem.note: This is the only recorded source of this poem.

msItem.title: The Abuses of the Age
msItem.incipit:
A yong man a rewler recheles
A olde manne a lechowr loueles
msItem.explicit:
A womman a rebawde shameles
Thes v shall neuer thrif blameles

msItem.note: Table of contents for the whole volume, in a fifteenth-century hand.
Blank except for pen trials.

msItem.author: Benedict Burgh
msItem.title: Cato Major
msItem.rubric:
S I deus est animus no
hic tibi precipue s
msItem.incipit:
ffor why that god is inwardly the wit
Of man and yeueth hym vnderstond
msItem.explicit:
Bi too & too my metre for to knyt
Nat causith me but simplenesse of wit
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit hic Cato dans castigamina nato
Isto Cato orator vnus vij prudencium Rome
Cato et Plato et cetera
Detur pro penna scriptori pulcra pu
msItem.note: Outer half of fol. 2r excised. Written below the explicit on fol. 29v are G. E. and J. Tþ.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Stans puer ad mensam
msItem.incipit:
M I dere child first thi sylue enabill
With alle hyn hert to vertuous disciplyne
msItem.explicit:
Yf ougth be amys in word sillable or dede
Put al defaute apone Iohn Lidgate

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A prayer upon the cross
msItem.incipit:
[A] pon a crosse naylid I was for the
Suffred deth to pay thi raunson
msItem.explicit:
Now for thi modrys meke meditation
At this request be to vs merciable

msItem.title: Erthe upon Erthe
msItem.incipit:
Whanne life is most louyd
And deth is most hatid
msItem.explicit:
So that erthe for the erthe
Stye vp to thi holy hille

msItem.title: The xxx virtues of the mass
msItem.incipit:
xxx vertewis schal haue he
what wolle the masse hire or se
msItem.explicit:
And louyth the masse with alle your mynde
And god wolle sende you a gode ende

supportDesc.support: Paper. One watermark throughout, not fully visible due to position.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame ruled in graphite, in 23-28 long lines. Ruled space 175 155

handDesc.handNote: One hand in a secretary script with elaborate ascenders and descenders.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 3r opens with a four-line blue initial with red flourishing.
Cato Major, fols. 2r-29v, contains Latin subheadings in red.
Fol. 30r, beginning Stans puer ad mensam, contains a three-line red Lombardic capital. All lines across fols. 30r-31v underlined in red.

Fol. 32v, beginning Erthe upon Erthe, opens with a two-line space for a decorated initial W but lacks initial. All lines across fols. 32v-35r have the first letter of each line in red, and brackets in red.
Fols. 35v-37v, containing The xxx virtues of the mass, have the first letter of each line in red, and brackets in red.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fabula duorum mercatorum
msItem.incipit:
IN Egypt whilom as I reede and fynde
ther dwellid a marchaunt of hih and gret estat
msItem.explicit:
Rith in to Egipt he is gon a geyn
Of heer freendschip what shold y you more seeyn
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly. MS Rawl. Poet contains 128 of 130 stanzas in rhyme royal. The catchword at the foot of fol.53v reads I say you platly (the first line of stanza 129), suggesting the text was originally complete but the last leaf has been lost. Between fols. 53 and 54 survives a stub in parchment.

layoutDesc.layout: No ruling. 28-32 long lines per page. Ruled space 190 115

handDesc.handNote: A formal secretary script with elements of Anglicana Formata.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 38r, beginning Fabula duorum mercatorum, opens with a five-line decorated initial in red with black flourishing.

msItem.note: blank.

msItem.title: Proverbs
msItem.rubric: This ffolowyng ben the Prouerbis of Wysdom
msItem.incipit:
The wyse man sayd to his sonnes
Thynke on the prouerbis, þat after comys
msItem.explicit:
God that syttyþe In Trynyte
On vs al haue mercy & pyte

msItem.title: The ten commandments
msItem.rubric: This folowyng ben the x comandmentes
msItem.incipit:
All false goddis þu shalt forsak
His name nott yn Idell take
msItem.explicit:
Couete þou no man is wyff
Nore no þyng þat to hym lyeþe
msItem.note: This is the only recorded witness of this poem.

msItem.title: Who of plenty will take no heed
msItem.incipit:
Myspend we nott fyve and fle we seven
Kepe we wel x & com to heven
msItem.explicit:
When man hath what wyll is
Then shewyth he whatt he is
msItem.note: Untitled in the manuscript and written under the same heading as the previous text.

msItem.title: Table of the kings described in the Chronicle of England (Brut Chronicle) to 1461
msItem.rubric:
Here ffolowyth the tabyll of all the kyngs that euer raignid
yn Englonde begynnyng fro the fyrst that ys to say from Brute
msItem.incipit:
Brute the fyrst kyng that euer
was yn Englond Raygnyd xxx yeres
msItem.explicit:
Henri the v Raygnd ix yeres
Henri the vi Raygnyd xxxx yeres
msItem.note: Index to the following item.

msItem.title: Chronicle of England (Brut Chronicle) to 1461
msItem.rubric:
[H] Ere begynneth a boke which
is called Brute the cronacle of
England
msItem.incipit:
[T]his boke treteth techeth and telleth of
kyngis and of pryncipall lordis that ...
msItem.explicit: lyfe we may come to the euerlastyng lyfe in the blisse of heuen Amen
msItem.note: Prose. From Brut to Edward IV's accession, A.D. 1461, interrupted at AD 1066 (fols. 115v-116r).

The text opens with an elaborate decorated initial T on fol. 57r containing 3 banderoles which read me gratia
plena
dominus tecum
msItem.bibl: Lister M. Matheson, The Prose Brut: The Development of a Middle English Chronicle, Medieval & Renaissance Texts & Studies (1998).

msItem.note: blank.

supportDesc.support: Paper. Contemporary foliation i-iiiixxxiiij (fols. 57-150) Four watermarks: 'Chien' (Briquet, 3626), 'Licorne' (Briquet, 10211), ‘Anneau’ (Briquet, 689), similar to 'Armoires sans pieces' (Briquet, 841).

layoutDesc.layout: Fols. 54v-56v in two columns, unruled, with 32-42 long lines. Written space c. 210 140
Fols. 57r-168r in one column, unruled, with 33-39 long lines.

handDesc.handNote: Four scribes, all writing in a Secretary script (fols. 54-56v, 57r-68v, 68v-115v, 116r-168r).

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 54v, beginning Proverbs, opens with a two-line space for a decorated initial W but lacks initial.
All lines across fols. 54v-55r have the first letter of each line in red, and brackets in red.
Fols. 55r-56v,The ten commandments and the table of kings from the Brut Chronicle, have rubricated title and explicit, the first letter of each line in red, and brackets in red.
Fol. 57r opens the Brut Chronicle (fols. 57r-168r) with a ten-line cadel initial containing banderoles.
Flourished ascenders on the top line.
Rubricated lombardic capitals throughout, with occasional red underlining. Titles and explicits in red.

origin.origDate: 15th century, second half (after 1480, see Matheson, p.276)

msContents.textLang: Middle English with (art. 3) marginal apparatus in Latin

msItem.note: blank.

msItem.title: The Fifteen O's of Christ
msItem.incipit:
O Ihesu Crist of euerlastynge swetnes
Thow god in thi godhed this to begyn
msItem.explicit:
And I to be made so worthy fro alle filthes infernall
Amonge thy Sayntes to prayse the with thaym perpetuall
msItem.finalRubric:
Aman without mercy of mercy shall mysse
He shall haue mercy that mercyfull ys
msItem.note: Thirty-four stanzas in rhyme royal. Ends with two provers written in red.

msItem.title: Libel of English Policy
msItem.rubric:
H ere begynneth the Prologe of the processe of þe bible of
Englishe Polycy exortyng alle Engelond to kepe the See ...
msItem.incipit:
T he trew processe of Engelond pollecye
Of Owteward to kepe this Realme in reste
msItem.explicit:
I offre the them to be gracious
To thyne excuse fare well myn owne trete
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit libellus de polecia
conseruatiua maris

msItem.note: blank.

layoutDesc.layout: Fols. 169v-172r: no ruling, 24 long lines consistently, written space 225 130
Fols. 173r-193r: frame ruled, with 29-31 long lines per page, ruled space 200 120

handDesc.handNote: One hand in a scretary script with elaborate ascenders and descenders.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 169v opens The Fifteen O's of Christ with a four-line flourished initial in black ink. Other first initials are flourished over fols.169v-172v.
Final rubric in red.
Fol. 173r opens Libel of English Policy with two-line red Lombardic capitals, also on fols. 190v and 191v. Fol. 190r has a two-line space for a missing Lombardic capital.
Across 173r-193r, the first letter of each line is in red until fol. 189v, and glosses are signalled in red, with occasional red underlining.

msItem.author: Stephen Scrope
msItem.title: Dicts and sayings of the philosophers
msItem.incipit: S edechias was the ffryst phylyzophere by whom as ...
msItem.explicit:
And thys suffysyth of the translacion of the morall sayyngles
off phylyzophowres etc.
msItem.finalRubric:
Hic est finis libri de moralibus
philosophorum R T
msItem.note: R. T. could refer to Richard Turnowre, whose name appears on fol. 205r.
Abbeviated version; this text pr. EETS o.s. 211, pp. 295-320.

msItem.title: The age of the worlde
msItem.incipit:
The first age of the worlde was from adam to Noye
The secund from Noye to Abraham
msItem.explicit:
In the begynnynng of the viij shalbe reysyng of all þat
ben dede and a reward[?] ffor good and euill

msItem.title: Teeth, Bones, and Veins
msItem.incipit:
XXXII teth that beþe full kene
CC bonys and Nyntene
msItem.explicit:
CCC vaynys syxty and fyve
Euery man haþe that is a lyve

msItem.note: Note containing dimensions of St Paul's Cathedral, London.

layoutDesc.layout: No ruling. 34-38 long lines per page. Ruled space 230 150

handDesc.handNote: Three hands in a secretary script (fols. 194r-204r, 204v, 205r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 194v, beginning A processe of philosophers, opens with a four-line red Lombardic capital. Also on fol. 197r.
Paraphs rubricated across 194r-204r. Rubricated explicit.
Fol. 204v, containing The age of the worlde, rubricates the first words of each section and line breaks.
Teeth, Bones, and Veins, fol. 205r, in red.
